Line 1: Line 1: â
[[Image:Ubuntu-jaunty.png|right|thumb|A screenshot of Ubuntu 9.04, the latest version of Ubuntu.]]
+
[[Image:Ubuntu.png|right|thumb|A screenshot of Ubuntu 9.04, the latest version of Ubuntu.]]
[[Ubuntu]], an [[operating system]] based on [[Debian|Debian GNU/Linux]], makes two releases every year, using the year and month of the release as a [[version number]]. The first Ubuntu release, for example, was Ubuntu 4.10 and was released on 20 October 2004.<ref name="warty_release">{{cite mailing list |url=https://lists.ubuntu.com/archives/ubuntu-announce/2004-October/000003.html |title=Ubuntu 4.10 announcement |date=2004-10-20 |accessdate=2008-08-19 |mailinglist=ubuntu-announce |last=Shuttleworth |first=Mark |authorlink=Mark Shuttleworth }}</ref> Consequently, version numbers for future versions are provisional; if the release is delayed until a different month to that planned, the version number changes accordingly.
[[Ubuntu]], an [[operating system]] based on [[Debian|Debian GNU/Linux]], makes two releases every year, using the year and month of the release as a [[version number]]. The first Ubuntu release, for example, was Ubuntu 4.10 and was released on 20 October 2004.<ref name="warty_release">{{cite mailing list |url=https://lists.ubuntu.com/archives/ubuntu-announce/2004-October/000003.html |title=Ubuntu 4.10 announcement |date=2004-10-20 |accessdate=2008-08-19 |mailinglist=ubuntu-announce |last=Shuttleworth |first=Mark |authorlink=Mark Shuttleworth }}</ref> Consequently, version numbers for future versions are provisional; if the release is delayed until a different month to that planned, the version number changes accordingly.
